content: double_crochet in next stitch** repeat from * to ** five times omitting final double_crochet join with slip_stitch to beginning double_crochet for round 11 114 double_crochet 6 ch2 12 ch1 138 stitches in total 12 slip_stitch into next stitch then ch3 *double_crochet in next three stitches double_crochet in ch1 space ch1 and skip next stitch double_crochet in next five stitches ch1 and skip next stitch as many times as necessary until there are three stitches left before the next ch2 space double_crochet in next stitch 2dc in next stitch and 2dc in ch2 space ch2 skip next stitch then double_crochet in next stitch** repeat from * to ** five times omitting final double_crochet join with slip_stitch to beginning double_crochet for round 12 120 double_crochet 6 ch2 18 ch1 150 stitches in total repeat rounds 10-12 making sure you add a new ch1 space on every third round ie add a new chain space on every round that is a multiple of three 12 15 18 21 24 etc you should always have five double_crochet between each ch1 space and either five seven or nine double_crochet between the final ch1 space of each segment and the ch2 space you may find it helpful to use stitch markers to keep track of where you need to increase on each round the increases should always be just before a ch2 space not a ch1 space when the blanket is the size you want work this round as a border ch1 turn blanket so you re working into the wrong/back side work a crab stitch into each stitch ch1 and ch2 space when you reach the beginning slip_stitch into first crab stitch break off yarn and sew in all ends blocking you may find you need to block your finished blanket to get it to lie flat for this yarn my preferred method is to wash the blanket tumble dry low until it is only slightly damp and then lay it flat to finish drying smoothing it out as necessary page 3 of 4 spin me around © catherine bligh page 4 of 4
